title: Apathy in Dementia Methylphenidate Trial 2
description_brief: Apathy in Dementia Methylphenidate Trial 2 (ADMET 2) is a Phase III, placebo-controlled, masked, 6 month, multi-center randomized clinical trial sponsored by National Institutes of Aging involving 200 participants with Alzheimer's disease (AD). ADMET 2 is designed to examine the efficacy and safety of methylphenidate as treatment for clinically significant apathy in AD participants. ADMET 2 will enroll participants from real world settings such as outpatient, nursing home, and assisted living facilities and will examine the effects of methylphenidate on apathy and cognition. ADMET 2 will also conduct careful safety monitoring.
description_detailed:
ADMET 2 will examine in a masked, randomized trial the efficacy of methylphenidate for the treatment of clinically significant apathy in participants with Alzheimer's dementia. Efficacy will be assessed as the change in Neuropsychiatric Inventory Apathy subscale (NPI apathy) from baseline to 6 months and score on the Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study - Clinical Global Impression of Change (CGIC) scale at 6 months.

ADMET 2 will also examine the safety of methylphenidate for the treatment of clinically significant apathy in participants with Alzheimer's disease by measuring vital signs, electrolyte panels, adverse event reports, and electrocardiograms. Safety will also be measured by examining neuropsychiatric symptoms other than apathy using the Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI).

Changes from baseline to 6 months in other neuropsychological assessments as measured using the Dementia Apathy Interview and Rating (DAIR) scale will also be assessed.

Cost-effectiveness will be measured by assessing quality of life and economic assessment and cognitive changes using a cognitive battery that includes the Mini Mental State Exam (MMSE) and other scales.

A biomarker sub-study initiated part-way through the main trial will collect information on blood-based biomarkers, including microRNA, markers of oxidative stress, inflammation, neuronal loss and lipidomics.

groups.title: Methylphenidate
groups.description:
Methylphenidate, target dose 20 mg per day (range 10-20 mg per day), in 5 mg over-capsulated tablets, and psychosocial intervention

Methylphenidate: Two 5mg methylphenidate over-encapsulated drug taken twice a day for 6 months (total of 20 mg methylphenidate per day), and psychosocial intervention

groups.description:

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcomeMeasures.title: Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI)
outcomeMeasures.description:
Mean difference in change from baseline to 6 months in the NPI apathy subscale scores as administered by certified personnel to the study caregiver.

SEVERITY is graded 1 to 3 and FREQUENCY is graded 1 to 4. The overall score for the domain is the product of the severity and frequency which ranges from 1 to 12 with higher scores indicating more apathy.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The number of participants with data at 6 months

outcomeMeasures.title: Percentage of Participants With Change in Modified Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study- Clinical Global Impression of Change (CGIC)
outcomeMeasures.description: Percentage of individuals improving on Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study- Clinical Global Impression of Change (CGIC) from baseline to 6 months; the CGIC is a 7-point Likert scale used to rate each patient with the following scores: "marked worsening"(7), "moderate worsening" (6), "minimal worsening"(5), "no change"(4), "minimal improvement"(3), "moderate improvement"(2), "marked improvement"(1). Ratings were based on an interview with the caregiver and an examination of the patient. The CGIC requires the clinician to consider a number of aspects of apathy, such as level of initiative, level of interest, and emotional engagement. Reported data is the percentage of participants with minimal/moderate/marked improvement.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The number of participants with data at 6 months

drug: methylphenidate (study dose: 20 mg/day; commonly given as 10 mg twice daily in ADMET2)
explanation_target: Reason: The trial (ADMET 2) tests methylphenidate specifically to treat clinically significant apathy in people with Alzheimer disease — a neuropsychiatric/behavioral symptom — and will assess apathy (NPI‑A) and cognition over 6 months, indicating a symptomatic/neuropsychiatric intent rather than targeting AD pathology. citeturn0search0turn0search4

Act: Key extracted details — intervention: methylphenidate vs matching placebo; phase III, randomized, placebo‑controlled, 6‑month trial enrolling ~200 AD participants with clinically significant apathy; dosing in the protocol is 20 mg/day (reported as 10 mg twice daily in the randomized trial reports). The trial's primary outcomes are change in apathy measures and global impression of change; cognition and safety are secondary outcomes. citeturn0search0turn0search3turn0search1

Mechanism / rationale: Methylphenidate is a central nervous system stimulant that increases synaptic dopamine and norepinephrine by blocking their reuptake (a norepinephrine–dopamine reuptake inhibitor). Its pharmacology is symptomatic (catecholaminergic) augmentation of motivation/attention, not a biologic or small‑molecule therapy aimed at amyloid or tau pathology. This supports classification as treatment of a neuropsychiatric symptom (apathy). citeturn1search0turn1search14

Reflect: Classification check — the intervention is NOT a monoclonal antibody or vaccine (so not a disease‑targeted biologic), nor is it a small molecule intended to modify Alzheimer pathology (so not disease‑targeted small molecule). Although methylphenidate can affect cognition, the trial's primary target is apathy (a neuropsychiatric symptom), so the correct category is 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement'. Trial results and safety reports describe modest benefit on apathy and safety monitoring consistent with a symptomatic psychiatric intervention. citeturn0search1turn0search2

Web search sources used (key results): PubMed study protocol for ADMET 2 (trial design and aims). citeturn0search0; ADMET2 primary results/publication (efficacy on apathy, 6‑month outcomes). citeturn0search1turn0search3; Trials listing / ClinicalTrials.gov summary for NCT02346201. citeturn0search4; Safety/adverse‑events analysis from ADMET2. citeturn0search2; Methylphenidate mechanism/pharmacology (StatPearls / NCBI Bookshelf and supporting pharmacology summaries). citeturn1search0turn1search14
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention (methylphenidate) works by blocking reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine, increasing synaptic catecholamines and producing symptomatic improvement in motivation/apathy rather than targeting AD pathology. This mechanism maps to CADRO's neurotransmitter systems category (D). citeturn0search0

Act: Key extracted trial details — ADMET2 is a randomized, placebo‑controlled, 6‑month, phase III trial (≈200 participants) testing methylphenidate 20 mg/day (10 mg twice daily) versus placebo with primary outcomes of apathy (NPI‑A) and global impression; it showed a modest but significant reduction in apathy favoring methylphenidate. These facts support a symptomatic, catecholaminergic (neurotransmitter) target. citeturn0search3turn0search1

Reflect: Classification check — although methylphenidate acts on monoamine transporters (reuptake inhibition rather than an ion channel or enzyme), CADRO's closest and most specific category is D) Neurotransmitter Receptors (covers interventions on neurotransmitter systems/monoaminergic signaling). The trial is symptom‑directed (neuropsychiatric improvement) and not disease‑modifying, so R) Multi‑target and T) Other are not appropriate. citeturn0search0turn0search3

Web search sources used: StatPearls summary of methylphenidate mechanism (reuptake inhibition of dopamine and norepinephrine). citeturn0search0; ADMET2 trial report / JAMA Neurology (PubMed) with design, dosing, outcomes and conclusions. citeturn0search3; ADMET2 abstract / Alzheimer's & Dementia (trial results and design summary). citeturn0search1
